entry.title: Coconut/Orange/Pineapple Sorbet
entry.content:
sor-bay? sher-bet?

I made my first "real" sorbet today! ("Real" being my way of distinguishing this sorbet from my actual first sorbet-making experience, in which I fastidiously measured out a cup of pineapple juice into a sorbet mixture, and then poured into the ice cream maker not this mixture, but the leftover pineapple juice. Whoops.)

I really adore ice cream and gave an ice cream maker to my mother last Christmas, which she gave back to me after admitting she'd probably never use it. Molly Moon's book -- with its color, environmentally friendly morals, and cheering that you can really do it, it's easy! -- is what really got me interested in trying to make ice cream. But, since it was on hold at the library, I found a different book to use for initial experiments.

this one! (source)

Recipe of the Week: Ice Cream: 52 Easy Recipes for Year-Round Frozen Treats is just as simple as Molly Moon's book, and it emphasizes using more fresh ingredients to enhance ice cream flavor. This is my source for the sorbet above, which is really just coconut milk, pineapple juice, and orange juice, with a little bit of cinnamon on top because it seemed like it needed something for the photo.

I didn't realize making ice cream was so easy. The ice cream maker, a contraption I always regarded as impermeably mysterious for some reason, is in fact just a sort of canister with frozen stuff in it, in which you're supposed to whip up your mixture such that it freezes along the sides and gets filled with air in the process. Most ice cream recipes seem like some variation of "Put cream and other things into a saucepan, bring it to a simmer, let it cool, then throw it in an ice cream maker."

Here's to a cool future.

entry.title: Butternut Squash Soup
entry.content:
Ever since my old roommate Molly made butternut squash a couple years ago, I've really wanted to try making it myself. My first experience with it was like whoa. Who knew such decadence could some from such an unassuming squash?

I found a recipe from the online version of Cook's Illustrated to try out, since other recipes I found toss in tons of cream and recommend roasting the squash to dehydrate it and bring out its flavor, and I didn't want to go through the extra effort and ingredients. What no one mentions, however, is that the most time-consuming part of cooking butternut squash soup is actually processing the squash in the first place. I tried three different knives to peel and cube this thing, each less sufficient than the last.

@_____@

The next obstacle was my lack of a Dutch oven, which is what the recipe suggests you cook everything in. An internet search seemed to suggest that any old pot with some foil put over the top of it would suffice, so I tried that, but then came across Problem #2: my pot was way too small to fit all the squash and leeks, much less another four cups of vegetable broth. So, I decided to cook two halves of the soon-to-be-soup separately, except probably this pot was really not the best pot to use in the first place, because it became severely burnt.

i really doubt this is the "fond" that's supposed to form at the pot's bottom

I moved to a shallower pan and that seemed to work.

...maybe?

By the time all of the squash had been boiled down, it still wasn't quite...soupy.

:C

I thought I would be okay without a blender, but the soup at this stage was very fibrous and chunky and unappealing. Enter Problem #3: I have no food processor!

Luckily the neighbors do, so we ran over there just to make use of their Vitamix.

YES. IT LOOKS LIKE SOUP. YESSS

Final touch: a swirl of sour cream, which sounded questionable but actually complemented the flavors very well.

woo!

It was delicious! Hopefully I'll have the chance to make this recipe again before the season's out.

entry.title: Bread and Pancakes
entry.content:
On the recommendation of my friend, I checked out Artisan Bread in 5 Minutes a Day from the library and attempted its secrets.

Having never made bread before and heard much of the difficulty of doing so, I was pretty skeptical. In the end it did not, in fact, take me five minutes, but forty or so minutes (from "cloaking" the bread to throwing it in the oven to eating it with delight) is not that bad.

My first attempt was remarkably crusty and white and fluffy inside.

WHOA. did i really do that?

My second attempt was crusted with soot as black as midnight and filled the entire house with smoke besides. But, the inside was still white and fluffy!

and edible!

Another first for me was creating pancakes from a macadamia-nut studded mix. I have to say that I kind of adore the speckled pattern that craters across pancake bottoms, all golden and moony.

now for the syrup

entry.title: A Recipe for Baked Potatoes
entry.content:
Real Talk: This is the only thing I cooked for myself all summer.

dat ingredients


Ingredients

  • 1 Russet Potato
  • 2 broccoli florets
  • 4 white mushrooms
  • some Jarlsberg cheese
  • pinches of rosemary, ground seasalt
Serves 1 (though to be honest, I'm always overly full when I finish, so you could probably split it)


Instructions

  1. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees Fahrenheit.
  2. Wash the potato, stab it all around with a fork, and then stick it in the oven. If you do not stab your potato with a fork or knife, it will explode.
  3. Wash everything and then begin cutting it up. Mushrooms I tend to mince, and for broccoli I tear up the florets by hand. I don't usually like the stem (despite it actually being sweeter than the florets), but it's easier for me to eat if I cut it up into small pieces. Might as well use all the pounds you paid for, right? Fun Fact: I can't find evidence of this now, but my old cooking teacher told me that it's better to tear broccoli rather than cut it. Fun Fact #2: We're not using it here, but this reminds me that I read garlic yields more of its nutrients to you if you mince it than if you leave it in chunks.

    i always really liked the cross-sections of mushrooms and broccoli stems

  4. Once the potato has been in for around 30 minutes, throw the broccoli into a pot of water and start bringing it to a boil. Once it starts boiling, turn the heat down low or turn it off completely and let it drain in a colander. This is to prevent the broccoli from becoming over-cooked and leaking all its nutrients into the water besides. (It's probably better to steam it, but I don't have a steamer and am always too lazy to look up hacky ways to steam.) The florets can hold a lot of water, so make sure you press out all the moisture either now or as you're eating so that stuff doesn't get soggy.
  5. Around this time, I also start frying the mushrooms. Specifically, I do it with Trader Joe's Spanish Olive Oil, and sprinkle on rosemary and freshly ground seasalt. Why freshly ground seasalt? Because when I searched the cabinets of the place I'm subletting, all I could find was a canister of large seasalt grains and a porcelain mortar and pestle.

    i wonder if it really makes the salt taste better

  6. Once the mushrooms start looking pretty cooked, turn down the heat. It'll depend on you how cooked you want the mushrooms to be, though I generally like them pretty brown myself. I wouldn't be frying them for more than 10 minutes or so.
  7. Once the potato has been in the oven for an hour and a half to two hours, take it out. I generally err on the side of waiting longer for the potato, since I love it when they're soft and mushy on the inside. Plus this makes the skin crispier!

    an armor of crunchy deliciousness


How to Eat

I generally slice the potato in half, put in liberal amounts of minced Jarlsberg, and then hold the potato closed so that it will all melt into gooey deliciousness. Then, eat with the mushrooms and broccoli in whatever proportions you desire.


mmmmmmmmm


Cost

Laziness always brings me to the closest grocery for ingredients, which happens to be Whole Foods. This is how much I spent at my last visit today:
  • White mushrooms, 0.40 lb at 3.99/lb -- $1.60
  • Broccoli crowns, 1.02 lb at 2.99/lb -- $3.06
  • Russet potato, 1.46 lb at 1.99/lb -- $2.91
  • Jarlsberg -- $4.00
  • Total: ~$11.57

Everything was organic and thus more expensive, but this sort of stuff always makes me aware that "eating healthy" can really be a class issue. I'm not saying that this is the healthiest meal on the planet, but it's probably better than a McDonalds dinner, with a trade-off that it's more expensive money-wise and time-wise. I'm privileged in that I don't work so hard each day that it's difficult for me to find time to cook, much less find time to cook for myself and a family. I mean, come on guys. $8 for two potatoes, 5 mushrooms, and 3 broccoli crowns?

entry.title: Avocado Tempura
entry.content:
Vegetable tempura is my favorite, and I once tried making avocado tempura, which was pretty alright, though it had kind of a strange smell and after-taste and was in general a little unremarkable. (Better use for avocados: as a substitute for cream cheese on bagels.)

That being said, I'm pretty sure the recipe involved doing something like this:
  1. Cut up some firm avocadoes
  2. Whisk around an egg
  3. Dip the avocado pieces in egg
  4. Roll them around in a composite of flour, salt, and pepper
  5. Deep-fry them until the coating is browned
  6. Eat with soy sauce and sake!


I'm definitely going to try and find a better way to do this.

not giving up on you just yet, bro
